docs.snippet: Whatever may be happening on the Falkland Islands, many Argentines, buoyed by optimistic press, television and radio reports, believe they are winning.   Though there are no signs that President Leopoldo Galtieri or the junta as a whole has planned a...
docs.lead_paragraph: Whatever may be happening on the Falkland Islands, many Argentines, buoyed by optimistic press, television and radio reports, believe they are winning. Though there are no signs that President Leopoldo Galtieri or the junta as a whole has planned a conscious public relations campaign aimed at Argentine opinion, the thrust of what is being printed and broadcast has been that Argentine planes and troops are thrashing the British. Conviccion, a newspaper that has ties to the navy, had a headline today on the British landing at Port San Carlos that said, ''The marines, immobilized at San Carlos, await their Dunkirk.'' A smaller headline adds, ''As Argentine troops concentrate to throw them into the sea, the British continue in the little beachhead without resupply.''

headline.main: PRESS TELLS ARGENTINES THAT THEY ARE WINNING

byline.original: By JAMES M. MARKHAM, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: The Cosmos announced today that Robert Iarusci, one of their sweepers, suffered a fractured vertebra in his lower spine and would be out for at least three weeks.   With Carlos Alberto, the other sweeper, nursing a hamstring strain, Coach Julio...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Cosmos announced today that Robert Iarusci, one of their sweepers, suffered a fractured vertebra in his lower spine and would be out for at least three weeks. With Carlos Alberto, the other sweeper, nursing a hamstring strain, Coach Julio Mazzei said that Ivan Buljan would be the sweeper in the Trans-Atlantic Challenge Cup game against Napoli of Italy Wednesday night at Giants Stadium. Iarusci's injury was discovered Monday, five days after it occurred in a game against Portland. The initial diagnosis was a bruise, but when Iarusci continued to complain of pain Monday, he was X-rayed by the team physician, Dr. John Xethalis.

byline.original: By ALEX YANNIS, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: The Cosmos and Napoli of Italy opened the third annual Trans-Atlantic Challenge Cup tonight by playing to a 2-2 tie at Giants Stadium before a crowd of 28,887.   All the goals came in the second half with Julio Cesar Romero scoring both for the...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Cosmos and Napoli of Italy opened the third annual Trans-Atlantic Challenge Cup tonight by playing to a 2-2 tie at Giants Stadium before a crowd of 28,887. All the goals came in the second half with Julio Cesar Romero scoring both for the Cosmos. Claudio Pellegrini matched Romero's first goal and Giuseppe Damiani put Napoli ahead before Romero's second goal tied the score in the 68th minute. There was no overtime period.

headline.main: Cosmos Tie Napoli on Romero's Goal, 2-2

byline.original: By ALEX YANNIS, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: Joe West, a 220-pound National League umpire, was on his way to work the Cubs-Padres game in San Diego when he saw a police officer chasing a theft suspect. He tackled the suspect, held him for the officer and went on to the ballpark. ... Bill Rogers, Craig Stadler and Bob Rosburg will be inducted into the All-American Collegiate Golf Hall of Fame at a dinner in Manhattan June 22. ... Roberto Cabanas, the Cosmos midfielder who has been sidelined with cracked veterbrae since last year's playoffs, will return to the lineup for tomorrow's game against Nacional of Uruguay in the Trans-Atlantic Challenge Cup tournament.

docs.snippet: As usual, this year's International Monetary Conference was a stylish affair, with much wining, dining and sightseeing. But unlike at previous sessions of the conference, there was unity here among the 250 bankers who attended: They all seemed to be...
docs.lead_paragraph: As usual, this year's International Monetary Conference was a stylish affair, with much wining, dining and sightseeing. But unlike at previous sessions of the conference, there was unity here among the 250 bankers who attended: They all seemed to be preoccupied with the same problems. Looming over the conference was the worldwide recession, which has caused a surge in problem loans around the globe. That, along with general unhappiness over high interest rates, government intervention - some called it interference - and increased competition from nonbank enterprises, created a sense among the bankers that they were all in the same boat.

headline.main: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: BANKERS IN A LEAKY BOAT

byline.original: By ROBERT A. BENNETT, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: Argentina's Foreign Minister, Nicanor Costa Mendez, delivered a scathing attack on the United States today for supporting Britain in the Falkland conflict, and he said the future of United States relations with Latin America ''is under threat.''  ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Argentina's Foreign Minister, Nicanor Costa Mendez, delivered a scathing attack on the United States today for supporting Britain in the Falkland conflict, and he said the future of United States relations with Latin America ''is under threat.'' ''The lesson is clear,'' Mr. Costa Mendez said at the opening of an emergency meeting of foreign ministers of the Organization of American States. ''We will have to take it into account when we plan the future of Latin America.'' Hours later at the meeting, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. urged ''compromise'' between Argentina and Britain. ''Is there a country among us that has not counted itself a friend of both countries?'' he asked.

headline.main: ARGENTINE ASSAILS U.S. AT O.A.S. TALKS

byline.original: By BERNARD WEINRAUB, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: The Argentine command said tonight that ground and air forces were battling to repel British troops trying to secure a position in the Darwin area south of Britain's beachhead on East Falkland Island.   The command issued a communique on the action...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Argentine command said tonight that ground and air forces were battling to repel British troops trying to secure a position in the Darwin area south of Britain's beachhead on East Falkland Island. The command issued a communique on the action moments after the British Defense Ministry announced in London that British forces had captured both Darwin and neighboring Goose Green. A communique issued tonight said the Argentines had begun their counterattack against the British with planes and infantry at 10 A.M., ''totally recovering the terrain, controlling the situation tactically and forcing them to fall back to the north.'' It added, however, that ''the actions continue at present,'' a possible acknowledgment that the British had renewed their ef In a later communique,, the command said the British had returned with reinforcements to the Darwin area and were conducting an active battle there.

headline.main: WAS THE ICE CREAM DOPED OR DOPEY?

docs.snippet: President Leopoldo Galtieri warned today that Argentina might seek help from ''other latitudes'' in its war with Britain over the Falkland Islands.   In an angry speech on Argentina's Army Day, General Galtieri alluded to United States support for...
docs.lead_paragraph: President Leopoldo Galtieri warned today that Argentina might seek help from ''other latitudes'' in its war with Britain over the Falkland Islands. In an angry speech on Argentina's Army Day, General Galtieri alluded to United States support for Britain, charging that ''certain governments'' were assisting ''the aggressor with a decision almost unheard of since the end of the Second World War.'' The statement appeared to be an oblique suggestion, the first from General Galtieri, that Argentina might turn to the Soviet Union. General Galtieri had been regarded as one of the most pro-United States leaders in Argentine history.

headline.main: ARGENTINE HINTING OF SHIFT TO SOVIET

byline.original: By EDWARD SCHUMACHER, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: The Cosmos defeated Nacional of Uruguay, 3-1, in the second round of the Trans-Atlantic Challenge Cup today before 14,212 fans. The crowd was the smallest to watch a soccer game at Giants Stadium since 1977, the Cosmos' first season here.   Roberto...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Cosmos defeated Nacional of Uruguay, 3-1, in the second round of the Trans-Atlantic Challenge Cup today before 14,212 fans. The crowd was the smallest to watch a soccer game at Giants Stadium since 1977, the Cosmos' first season here. Roberto Cabanas, sidelined for nine months because of four fractured vertebrae in his spine, returned to the lineup and scored the first goal for the Cosmos in the 11th minute. Nacional tied the score in the 42d minute on Wilmar Cabrera's low shot past Hubert Birkenmeier, the goalkeeper. Birkenmeier only made one save as Nacional played a cautious, defensive game.

byline.original: By ALEX YANNIS, Special to the New York Times
